head.headtext: Statements for purposes of medical diagnosis or treatment

para.paratext: Federal Rule of Evidence 803(4) excludes from the hearsay rule any declarations of physical condition made for the purpose of medical diagnosis or treatment. This rule is identical to Georgia's former O.C.G.A. § 24-3-4 (now O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(4)).

Under O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(4), “[s]tatements made for purposes of medical diagnosis or treatment and describing medical history, or past or present symptoms, pain, or sensations, or the inception or general character of the cause or external source thereof insofar as reasonably pertinent to diagnosis or treatment” shall not be excluded by the hearsay rule.

The previous version of this statute was applied in Banks v. State[1] to permit a nurse to testify about a child's emergency room statement of what had happened to her because the statements were pertinent to the child's diagnosis and treatment.

The history that a patient gives to a psychologist, nurse, pediatrician, licensed professional counselor, or emergency room physician during examination or treatment has been held admissible under this exception to the hearsay rule.[2] However, this exception relates only to patient statements and does not permit the admission of medical opinion included in a hospital record.[3]

The exception has been applied only to statements that are pertinent to the “diagnosis or treatment” of the patient. In Johnson v. State,[4] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that statements by an incest victim regarding previous acts of incest were not pertinent to diagnosis or treatment. In State v. Almanza,[5] the Court of Appeals excluded statements by the mother made to the attending physicians as to the identification of the defendant during her daughter's physical examination; however, Almanza was overruled by the Georgia Supreme Court,[6] which held that identification of a defendant by a child declarant during an examination by a physician may be admissible under the test set out by the Eighth Circuit in U.S. v. Renville.[7] Thus, to be allowed under O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(4), the trial court must determine (1) that the declarant's motive in making the statement is consistent with the purposes of promoting diagnosis or treatment, and (2) that the content of the statement was reasonably relied on by a physician in treatment or diagnosis. This two-step test ensures that the hearsay statement has a sufficient guarantee of trustworthiness.

Similarly, in Lewis v. State,[8] the court held that remarks identifying the defendant were not admissible because the statements must be made by or on behalf of a patient seeking medical aid. Thus, in Pirkle v. Hawley,[9] the court held admissible under former O.C.G.A. § 24-3-4[10] statements that the plaintiff had stopped breathing, which were made to a police officer at the scene of a traffic accident. Also, an emergency medical technicians' testimony regarding defendants' admitted drug use on the night before the traffic accident was admissible as pertinent in the provision of emergency medical treatment.[11] The Supreme Court in Neuman v. State,[12] opined that statements in a psychotherapist's notes, made during individual counseling sessions with the defendant's wife, which the psychotherapist used for medical diagnosis or treatment were not admissible under former O.C.G.A. § 24-3-4, but rather were privileged communications between the psychotherapist and the defendant's wife.
